comments.author: Molly
comments.content: should not read food blogs when hungry. yum!

comments.author: Appetite for Conversation
comments.content: Looks fantastic!  I bet the same method would make a great quesadilla, too.  Yum.

comments.author: Ellen
comments.content: i always mix parmesan into the butter on my grilled cheese sandwiches. a similar effect, but i never though about taking it to the next level! i bet you'll win this contest! awesome.

comments.author: Rowan Watson
comments.content: yum. can i say it again? frakkin YUM! you are my culinary idol, right up there with julia child, who taught me how to cook with booze (among other things) ha ha ha

comments.author: lisaiscooking
comments.content: This is genius! I want to run to the kitchen and try this now.

comments.author: Liz
comments.content: That is awesome. I am kind of a purist when it comes to my grilled cheese sandwiches, but I can definitely get on board some cheesy crunchiness added to it.

comments.author: John - Mormon Foodie
comments.content: You've done it again, Michael. Awesome way to kick up the classic grilled cheese, I must say. There are some local cheeses I'm anxious to try this with.

comments.author: Dawn (KitchenTravels)
comments.content: Michael - you are either an evil genius or a brilliant angel. Whatever, as long as you keep churning out ideas like this one.

comments.author: Amanda
comments.content: Yum! Have you submitted this to the Grilled Cheese Academy yet? http://www.grilledcheeseacademy.com/submitrecipe

comments.author: Moira
comments.content: I discovered frico in 'Biba's Italian Kitchen' cookbook when my kids were little.  Her recipe is a 1 to 1 mixture of grated potato and grated cheese with a dash of salt.  Cook them in a small skillet, one at a time.  Don't bother putting plates out ... they'll disappear off the stove as each one comes out of the pan!  I've never tried keeping them warm ... they've never lasted long enough to bother!
